bug.short_desc: Trees display incorrectly on expand, or not at all, with Firefox 3.1 beta 2

long_desc.thetext:
I'm using Firefox 3.1 beta 2 on Mac OS X.
(I'm not sure if this is a Firefox or a qooxdoo bug - either way I guess you'd want to know about it).
Using http://demo.qooxdoo.org/0.7.4/showcase/#Tree, the first child element of a sub-tree is displayed incorrectly when the sub-tree is expanded. Closing and re-expanding the sub-tree fixes . Specifically, the text of the element is displayed at the right height, but hard against the left of the tree area. The icon and expander are either not displayed or occluded - they're invisible in any case, even with short labels.
I've observed this in the showcase, and also in an Eclipse RAP application (latest RAP CVS, including qooxdoo 0.7.4).
I have also observed intermittently tree controls in a RAP application not displaying at all, although reloading the view fixes this.
The trees in the 0.8 showcase don't appear to be affected by this.

I see similar, but not as severe glitches on Firefox 3.1 beta 2 on Windows. It appears the first child element of the first sub-tree opened is sometimes aligned incorrectly - everything else works fine, and closing/reopening the tree doesn't fix the layout.

Comment of duplicate bug #2105:
URL: http://demo.qooxdoo.org/0.7.4/demobrowser/#example~Tree_1.html
Steps to reproduce 1. open the URL given above with Firefox 3.1 beta 3 (factory settings) 2. load the "Tree 1" demo 3. expand the "Desktop" node 4. see that "Workspace" and "Trash" appear on the left hand side
*** Bug 2105 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Changing (platform) property as of bug 2231 -- sorry for the mass mailing.
3.5 beta 4 appears to have fixed this. All of the linked tree examples, and trees in Eclipse RAP appear to work fine.

Tim, thanks for keeping an eye on this issue that you brought to general attention in the first place.
Great to see the issue seems to be resolved in a newer beta release of FF. I'll close this bug as INVALID, since the intermediate beta versions of FF shouldn't really be relevant to typical users.
